Coordination polymer formulated as [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O having three-dimensional network was hydrothermally synthesized (H2PDA is 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The polymer crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 21/c, unit cell parameters: a = 21.7025(2) Ǻ, b = 10.03560(10) Ǻ, c = 14.03430(10) Ǻ, β = 91.7110(10)° (Z = 4), and exhibits a three-dimensional porous framework. The polymer contains two and four crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions and 1,4-phenylenediacetate anions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO−) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. The coordination polymer chains are reinforced by well-directed hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules. The polymer is mesoporous in nature with average pore size diameter of 5.6 nm. The polymer exhibits intense emission bands in visible region upon excitation at 390 nm. The polymer is thermally robust and undergoes thermal decomposition in well-defined steps.

Introduction

Over the last two decades, developments in the field of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) achieved new height [1–4]. Coordination polymers have been synthesized rapidly because distinct voids and channels in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of current interest [5]. PCPs act as host, whereas guest molecule can be introduced reversibly without collapse of framework. Depending on flexibility of ligands which results in structural diversity, MOFs have potential applications in wide areas such as gas storage [6–8], magnetism [9], separation, optics or catalysis [10–12], luminescent materials [13–15], radiopharmaceuticals [16], optoelectronics [17, 18], and MRI contrast agents. The parameters which control desired topology and physical properties of MOFs are metal centre, coordination functional group, and as well as the geometry of the ligand molecule [19, 20]. Therefore, selection of metal centre, pillared ligand molecule, and functionality are of central importance in MOF synthesis, as these govern the self-assembly process.

The synthesis, functionality, and applications of metal-organic frameworks and self-assembled supramolecular coordination complexes have been reviewed recently [21–24]. The design and construction of lanthanide-metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) based on the judicious selection of ligands and metal ions have become a very attractive research area. The reversible incorporation of auxiliary ligand is easier in case of lanthanide–organic framework than d-block organic framework as the lanthanides have higher coordination number [25]. This high coordination number plays a crucial role in designing the different MOF architecture. It is well known that trivalent lanthanide ions are fascinating luminescence sources owing to their high color purity and relatively long lifetimes arising from electronic transitions within the partially filled 4f-shell of the ions [26, 27]. A variety of multicarboxylate triazine/imidazoline/pyridine-based MOFs containing transition and lanthanide metals have been extensively studied and found to exhibit various coordination modes accompanying diversity of structures with consequent varying adsorptions, magnetic and luminescent properties [21, 28–30]. However, among various strategies, most of the work has focused on assembly of d-block metal-organic frameworks, and analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions still remains less developed. As lanthanide ions are hard acid, they have strong attractions for the hard bases, like O− of carboxylate groups. While selecting the bridging moiety, the rigid ones get priority over flexible ones because they impart stability to lanthanides-MOF [31].

In case of porous-lanthanides organic framework, the flexibility plays a crucial role. Therefore, we have used p-phenylenediacetic acid as bridging ligand in which carboxylate groups are connected to flexible C-atom which provide open channels and voids in lanthanides-MOF. In continuation of our work on coordination polymers with multifunctional ligands [32, 33], we report here the holmium(III) coordination polymer using 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) as ligand.

Results and discussion

The reaction of 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) with holmium nitrate pentahydrate in the presence of ethanol and water under hydrothermal conditions resulted in formation of light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O. Polymer is stable in air and insoluble in most organic solvents. The polymer has been characterized by elemental analysis, FTIR spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, N2 TPD-BET surface area, luminescence, and TGA studies.

FTIR spectrum of [Ho<sub>2</sub>(PDA)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>·2nH<sub>2</sub>O

FTIR of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O shows indicative vibrational bands of carboxylate groups and water molecules (see Fig. S1, Supplementary Material). Broad bands in the higher energy region at 3,426 and 3,029 cm−1 are attributed to υ(O–H) of coordinated and lattice water molecules. Sharp bands at 956 and 664 cm−1 are assigned to rocking ρr(H2O) and wagging ρw(H2O) modes of coordinated water molecule, respectively. Absence of bands in the region around 1,700 cm−1 indicates complete deprotonation of all the carboxylic acid groups in the polymer. The IR spectrum of polymer showed strong bands at 1,596 and 1,402 cm−1 assigned to the υas(COO) and υs(COO) modes, respectively. The in-plane δ(OCO) vibration mode appears as sharp band at 762 cm−1. Weak band at 2,924 cm−1 has been assigned to υ(C–H) of phenylene ring. The bands for δ(C–H) of phenylene ring appear at 1,325 and 868 cm−1.

Description of crystal structure

The crystallographic analysis of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O shows that structure of polymer consists of three-dimensional MOF with water molecules of crystallization occupying the porous voids. Relevant cell parameters and refinement results are summarized in Table 1. Two crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are present in polymer. Figure 1 shows the metal coordination environment in [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O. The coordination number around Ho(1) is nine, whereas it is eight around Ho(2). Both metal ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are coordinated to eight oxygen atoms of six carboxylate (COO−) groups of different PDA2− anions. The Ho(1) is additionally coordinated to oxygen atom of a water molecule generating a nine-coordinated tricapped trigonal prism constituted by OW(1), O(2), O(3), O(4), O(5), O(6), O(7), O(12), and O(13). The coordination geometry around eight-coordinated Ho(2) is close to dodecahedron and is constituted by O(2), O(4), O(5), O(8), O(9), O(10), O(11), and O(13).

The Ho–O (carboxylate) bond distances range from 2.255(2) to 2.703(3) Å and bond length of Ho–O (aqua) bond is 2.370(3) Å. All the bond lengths are within the range of those observed for other eight- or nine-coordinate Ho(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands [34]. Selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table 2. There are four crystallographically independent dicarboxylate PDA2− ligands in polymer [PDA(1), PDA(2), PDA(3), and PDA(4)] corresponding to O(11)O(2)C(21), O(7)O(8)C(6), O(6)O(9)C(26)C(1)O(3)O(4), and O(12)O(13)C(11)C(15)O(5)O(10) sets of atoms, respectively. Different modes of bonding adopted by PDA2− ligand are presented in Scheme 1. All four PDAs [PDA(1), PDA(2), PDA(3), and PDA(4)] use two carboxylate groups to coordinate the holmium atoms but through different coordination modes. PDA(1) adopts the μ2O;κ2OO′ coordination mode [bidentate through O(2) and O(11) toward Ho(2) and monodentate across O(2) towards Ho(1), and the atoms symmetry-related], whereas PDA(2) acts as a tetrakis-monodentate ligand [from O(7) and O(8) toward Ho(1) and Ho(2), respectively, and the atoms related by the inversion center]. PDA(3) acts as a bridge through its two carboxylate groups, one of them [O(6)-C(26)-O(9)] adopting the syn–syn coordination mode [coordination of O(6) and O(9) to Ho(1) and Ho(2), respectively] and the other [O(3)-C(1)-O(4)] exhibiting μ2O;κ2OO′ coordination mode [bidentate through O(3) and O(4) toward Ho(1) and monodentate across O(4) towards Ho(2)]. PDA(4) also adopts the μ2O;κ2OO′ coordination mode through its both carboxylate groups [bidentate through O(12) and O(13) toward Ho(1) and monodentate across O(13) towards Ho(2); bidentate through O(5) and O(10) toward Ho(2) and monodentate across O(5) towards Ho(1)].

Isomorphous structures of polymers of PDA2− anion with other lanthanide ions La(III), Nd(III), Sm(III), and Er(III) have been reported [35, 36]. The Er–O (carboxylate) bond distances ranged from 2.239(7) to 2.677(8) Å, whereas Er–O (aqua) bond was 2.267(7) Å.

In the polymeric structure of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O (1), the Ho(III) ions are interconnected through COO− groups, forming what may be viewed as an Ho-COO triple helix that extends in the crystallographic c-direction (Fig. 2). Figures 3, 4 and 5 give packing of polymer along a-, b-, and c-crystallographic directions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO−) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. One bridging COO− involves bis-monodentate syn–syn bonding (e.g., –O7–C6–O8–), whereas second and third have tridentate μ2O;κ2OO′ (e.g., –O11–C21–O2– and –O13–C11–O12–) bonding modes. The regular alternating of two types of Ho(III) ions which serve as nodes for bridging dicarboxylate PDA anions generates a polymeric chain.

This chain acts as SBU (secondary building block) and on further cross-linked via the –CH2C6H4CH2– spacers of the PDA anions results in 3D network of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O, which is reminiscent of the shape of a compressed honeycomb, showing 1D open channels (Fig. 5). The guest water molecules suspend in the channels and the coordinated water molecules point away from the Ho-PDA framework and into the channels. The polymer has 1D open channels when viewed along c-axis. The hydrogen atoms of guest water molecules and methylene carbon of ligand (PDA) are extensively involved in hydrogen bonding with oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups. Table 3 lists hydrogen-bond distances and angles.

N<sub>2</sub> TPD and BET surface area

The N2 adsorption isotherm of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O (see Fig. S2, Supplementary Material) has a gradual initial uptake and shows hysteresis, which indicates presence of mesopores. The absence of a rounded knee in the isotherm indicates a weak adsorbate–adsorbent interaction. According to IUPAC classification, this coordination polymer exhibits a type IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis. The hysteresis feature of type IV isotherm is associated with capillary condensation taking place within mesopores. The hysteresis loop, which does not exhibit any limiting adsorption at high P/P0, indicates the presence of slit-shaped pores in coordination polymer network. Large gap between adsorption and desorption curves at lower P/P0 values indicates presence of ink-bottle type pores.

The specific surface area determined from multipoint BET plot (see Fig. S3, Supplementary Material) is 45.37 m2/g with a slope 70.95, Y-intercept 5.80, correlation coefficient 0.998,725, and BET C constant 13.23. The value of BET C constant suggests a low heat of adsorption. The Langmuir surface area is found somewhat higher (98.62 m2/g) with a slope of 35.31, Y-intercept 8.814, correlation coefficient 0.999781, and Langmuir constant 4.0064.

A t-method micropore analysis (de Boer) of polymer (see Fig. S4, Supplementary Material) gives a linear V–t–plot with Y-intercept 15.02 cm3/g and slope 1.946. The linear plot along with the non-zero intercept suggests that [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O is mesoporous. Both the micropore volume and micropore surface area are 0.023 cm3/g and 15.27 m2/g, whereas the external surface area is 30.10 m2/g with a correlation coefficient of 1.000. This is almost the same as the BET surface area. The pore size distribution pattern was obtained from desorption branch by employing the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model (see Fig. S5, Supplementary Material). The plot shows that there is a wide distribution of pores in the polymer with diameters ranging from 3 nm to more than 13 nm with an average of 5.6 nm. The total pore volume is 0.06357 cm3/g for pores smaller than 21.57 nm at P/P0 = 0.90386.

Photoluminescence studies

Figure 6 shows the photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O. The excitation spectrum shows an excitation peak at about 390 nm which is assigned to 5I8 → 5G5 electronic transition in Ho3+ ion. The emission spectrum for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm shows three emission bands peaking at ~460, ~490, and ~545 nm corresponding to 5F2 → 5I8, 5F3 → 5I8, 5F4 → 5I8 transitions. Similar emission bands (not shown here) were observed with 430 nm excited wavelength. In general, purity in color of substance can be recognized by means of color coordinates. Hence, in our present work, the chromaticity coordinates of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O have been calculated from the emission spectrum using the commission international De I’Eclairage (CIE) system. The CIE chromaticity diagram for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm is shown in Fig. 7. The CIE coordinate is found to be (0.28, 0.38) which lies within the blue/hue region. Therefore, it may be concluded that the developed polymer could serve as a blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.

Thermal analysis

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of coordination polymer [Ho2(PDA)3 H2O]n·2nH2O are shown in Fig. 8. The thermal decomposition was investigated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 293 to 1,273 K at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The coordination polymer network is stable up to 373 K. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve shows that decomposition of the polymer takes place in three steps. The first step starts at 373 K and ends at 463 K. The residual weight at 463 K is 88 % (calculated weight loss = 88.55 %) corresponding to loss of three water molecules and two molecules of carbon monoxide. The DTA curve has a sharp endothermic peak at 453 K, indicating the loss of three water molecules. The second step of thermal decomposition has onset at 463 K and ends at 793 K. The residual weight at 793 K is 72 % (calculated weight loss = 72.3 %) indicating the loss of four molecules of carbon monoxide and one molecule of acetaldehyde. The third step has onset from 793 K with gradual weight loss up to 1,250 K, this step involves the loss of two molecules of phenyl acetaldehyde. Sharp DTA curve at 683 K and broad DTA curve at 963 K indicate decomposition of organic ligand. The residual weight at 1,267 K is 47.5 % (calculated weight loss = 46.5 %) corresponding to formation of Ho2O3 and carbon as end product.

Conclusions

The coordination polymer diaquatris(1,4-phenylenediacetato)diholmium(III) dihydrate, [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O having three-dimensional network, has been synthesized by hydrothermal method. On the basis of physicochemical studies and single-crystal diffraction studies, we conclude that the polymer has 3D compressed honeycomb shape having 1D open channels. The polymer is porous as is evident from the BET surface area study. The photoluminescent properties indicate that polymer can serve as blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.

Experimental

All materials used for synthesis were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on CHNS-932 Leco elemental analyzer. IR spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum RX-IFTIR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets from 400 to 4,000 cm−1. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra were measured at room temperature using Agilent Cary Eclipse Fluorescence Spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp that was used as an excitation source. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e in nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

Diaquatris(1,4-phenylenediacetato)diholmium(III) dihydrate (1, C<sub>30</sub>H<sub>30</sub>Ho<sub>2</sub>O<sub>15</sub>)

A mixture of 0.353 g Ho(NO3)3·5H2O (0.80 mmol) and 0.095 g 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 cm3 of deionized water and 1 cm3 of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried; Yield ~0.3 g (64 % based on H2PDA). The crystals were manually selected for structural determination and further characterization.

X-ray crystallographic study: crystal structure and refinement

The structure of the compound [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. X-ray intensity data of 23,635 reflections (of which 5,379 unique) were collected on a CCD Agilent Technologies (Oxford Diffraction) SUPER NOVA diffractometer. Data were collected at 150(2) K using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The strategy for data collection was evaluated using the CrysAlisPro CCD software. The data were collected by standard ‘φ–ω’ scan techniques, and were scaled and reduced using CrysAlisPro RED software. The cell dimensions were determined by least-square fit of angular settings of 23,635 reflections in the θ range 2.90°–25.00°. The intensities were measured by ω scan mode for θ range 2.90°–25.00°. Data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization factors, and absorption effects. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [37] and refined by full matrix least-squares with SHELXL-97, refining on F2 [38]. The positions of all the atoms were obtained by direct methods. All non-H-atoms were refined anisotropically. The remaining H-atoms were placed in geometrically constrained positions and refined with isotropic temperature factors, generally 1.2 Ueq of their parent atoms. Complete crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited in the CIF format with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication no. CCDC 938975. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK [fax: (44) 1223336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk].

N<sub>2</sub> TPD and BET surface area

The specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter were measured by N2 adsorption–desorption method using a NOVA 1200 (Quanta chrome) instrument. The bath temperature was maintained at 77 K. The sample was degassed at 423 K for 12 h before measurement. Pore size distribution and pore volume were obtained by applying the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) analysis to the adsorption branch of the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms. The specific surface area of the sample was calculated using the BET method. Micropore surface area and micropore volume were determined from t-plot analysis. All the flow rates were maintained at normal temperature and pressure.

elements.clean_text: ]>This XML was provided by Springer Naturedoi:10.1007/s00706-014-1289-331aa4ebcea41b6792ab66adebe5119a0/kaist-api1110170610.1007/706.1434-4475Monatshefte für Chemie - Chemical MonthlyAn International Journal of ChemistryMonatsh Chem0026-92471434-4475Springer ViennaViennas00706-014-1289-3128910.1007/s00706-014-1289-3Original PaperHydrothermal synthesis, structure, porosity, and luminescent properties of 3D coordination polymer of holmium with 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2OYawerMohd1SharmaSwati1KariemMukaddus1SheikhHaq N.1dSharmaMohita11grid.412986.00000000107054560Post-Graduate Department of ChemistryUniversity of JammuJammu Tawi180 006JammuIndiadhnsheikh@rediffmail.com49201412015146147551820142222014182014492014© Springer-Verlag Wien 20142014AbstractCoordination polymer formulated as [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O having  three-dimensional network was hydrothermally synthesized (H2PDA is 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The polymer crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 21/c, unit cell parameters: a = 21.7025(2) Ǻ, b = 10.03560(10) Ǻ, c = 14.03430(10) Ǻ, β = 91.7110(10)° (Z = 4), and exhibits a three-dimensional porous framework. The polymer contains two and four crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions and 1,4-phenylenediacetate anions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO-) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. The coordination polymer chains are reinforced by well-directed hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules. The polymer is mesoporous in nature with average pore size diameter of 5.6 nm. The polymer exhibits intense emission bands in visible region upon excitation at 390 nm. The polymer is thermally robust and undergoes thermal decomposition in well-defined steps.Graphical AbstractKeywordsHydrothermal synthesisCoordination polymer1,4-Phenylenediacetic acidMesoporousPhotoluminescencepublisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count12issue-article-count23issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2015issue-copyright-holderSpringer-Verlag Wienissue-copyright-year2015article-contains-esmYesarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2014article-registration-date-month8article-registration-date-day1article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/706_2014_Article_1289.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2015issue-online-date-month1issue-online-date-day1issue-print-date-year2014issue-print-date-month12issue-print-date-day31issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryChemistry/Food Science, generaljournal-subject-secondaryOrganic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryAnalytical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryTheoretical and Computational Chemistryjournal-subject-collectionChemistry and Materials Scienceopen-accessfalseElectronic supplementary materialThe online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s00706-014-1289-3) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.IntroductionOver the last two decades, developments in the field of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) achieved new height [1-4]. Coordination polymers have been synthesized rapidly because distinct voids and channels in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of current interest [5]. PCPs act as host, whereas guest molecule can be introduced reversibly without collapse of framework. Depending on flexibility of ligands which results in structural diversity, MOFs have potential applications in wide areas such as gas storage [6-8], magnetism [9], separation, optics or catalysis [10-12], luminescent materials [13-15], radiopharmaceuticals [16], optoelectronics [17, 18], and MRI contrast agents. The parameters which control desired topology and physical properties of MOFs are metal centre, coordination functional group, and as well as the geometry of the ligand molecule [19, 20]. Therefore, selection of metal centre, pillared ligand molecule, and functionality are of central importance in MOF synthesis, as these govern the self-assembly process.The synthesis, functionality, and applications of metal-organic frameworks and self-assembled supramolecular coordination complexes have been reviewed recently [21-24]. The design and construction of lanthanide-metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) based on the judicious selection of ligands and metal ions have become a very attractive research area. The reversible incorporation of auxiliary ligand is easier in case of lanthanide-organic framework than d-block organic framework as the lanthanides have higher coordination number [25]. This high coordination number plays a crucial role in designing the different MOF architecture. It is well known that trivalent lanthanide ions are fascinating luminescence sources owing to their high color purity and relatively long lifetimes arising from electronic transitions within the partially filled 4f-shell of the ions [26, 27]. A variety of multicarboxylate triazine/imidazoline/pyridine-based MOFs containing transition and lanthanide metals have been extensively studied and found to exhibit various coordination modes accompanying diversity of structures with consequent varying adsorptions, magnetic and luminescent properties [21, 28-30]. However, among various strategies, most of the work has focused on assembly of d-block metal-organic frameworks, and analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions still remains less developed. As lanthanide ions are hard acid, they have strong attractions for the hard bases, like O- of carboxylate groups. While selecting the bridging moiety, the rigid ones get priority over flexible ones because they impart stability to lanthanides-MOF [31].In case of porous-lanthanides organic framework, the flexibility plays a crucial role. Therefore, we have used p-phenylenediacetic acid as bridging ligand in which carboxylate groups are connected to flexible C-atom which provide open channels and voids in lanthanides-MOF. In continuation of our work on coordination polymers with multifunctional ligands [32, 33], we report here the holmium(III) coordination polymer using 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) as ligand.Results and discussionThe reaction of 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) with holmium nitrate pentahydrate in the presence of ethanol and water under hydrothermal conditions resulted in formation of light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O. Polymer is stable in air and insoluble in most organic solvents. The polymer has been characterized by elemental analysis, FTIR spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, N2 TPD-BET surface area, luminescence, and TGA studies.FTIR spectrum of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2OFTIR of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O shows indicative vibrational bands of carboxylate groups and water molecules (see Fig. S1, Supplementary Material). Broad bands in the higher energy region at 3,426 and 3,029 cm-1 are attributed to υ(O-H) of coordinated and lattice water molecules. Sharp bands at 956 and 664 cm-1 are assigned to rocking ρr(H2O) and wagging ρw(H2O) modes of coordinated water molecule, respectively. Absence of bands in the region around 1,700 cm-1 indicates complete deprotonation of all the carboxylic acid groups in the polymer. The IR spectrum of polymer showed strong bands at 1,596 and 1,402 cm-1 assigned to the υas(COO) and υs(COO) modes, respectively. The in-plane δ(OCO) vibration mode appears as sharp band at 762 cm-1. Weak band at 2,924 cm-1 has been assigned to υ(C-H) of phenylene ring. The bands for δ(C-H) of phenylene ring appear at 1,325 and 868 cm-1.Description of crystal structureThe crystallographic analysis of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O shows that structure of polymer consists of three-dimensional MOF with water molecules of crystallization occupying the porous voids. Relevant cell parameters and refinement results are summarized in Table 1. Two crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are present in polymer. Figure 1 shows the metal coordination environment in [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O. The coordination number around Ho(1) is nine, whereas it is eight around Ho(2). Both metal ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are coordinated to eight oxygen atoms of six carboxylate (COO-) groups of different PDA2- anions. The Ho(1) is additionally coordinated to oxygen atom of a water molecule generating a nine-coordinated tricapped trigonal prism constituted by OW(1), O(2), O(3), O(4), O(5), O(6), O(7), O(12), and O(13). The coordination geometry around eight-coordinated Ho(2) is close to dodecahedron and is constituted by O(2), O(4), O(5), O(8), O(9), O(10), O(11), and O(13).The Ho-O (carboxylate) bond distances range from 2.255(2) to 2.703(3) Å and bond length of Ho-O (aqua) bond is 2.370(3) Å. All the bond lengths are within the range of those observed for other eight- or nine-coordinate Ho(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands [34]. Selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table 2. There are four crystallographically independent dicarboxylate PDA2- ligands in polymer [PDA(1), PDA(2), PDA(3), and PDA(4)] corresponding to O(11)O(2)C(21), O(7)O(8)C(6), O(6)O(9)C(26)C(1)O(3)O(4), and O(12)O(13)C(11)C(15)O(5)O(10) sets of atoms, respectively. Different modes of bonding adopted by PDA2- ligand are presented in Scheme 1. All four PDAs [PDA(1), PDA(2), PDA(3), and PDA(4)] use two carboxylate groups to coordinate the holmium atoms but through different coordination modes. PDA(1) adopts the μ2O;κ2OO' coordination mode [bidentate through O(2) and O(11) toward Ho(2) and monodentate across O(2) towards Ho(1), and the atoms symmetry-related], whereas PDA(2) acts as a tetrakis-monodentate ligand [from O(7) and O(8) toward Ho(1) and Ho(2), respectively, and the atoms related by the inversion center]. PDA(3) acts as a bridge through its two carboxylate groups, one of them [O(6)-C(26)-O(9)] adopting the syn-syn coordination mode [coordination of O(6) and O(9) to Ho(1) and Ho(2), respectively] and the other [O(3)-C(1)-O(4)] exhibiting μ2O;κ2OO' coordination mode [bidentate through O(3) and O(4) toward Ho(1) and monodentate across O(4) towards Ho(2)]. PDA(4) also adopts the μ2O;κ2OO' coordination mode through its both carboxylate groups [bidentate through O(12) and O(13) toward Ho(1) and monodentate across O(13) towards Ho(2); bidentate through O(5) and O(10) toward Ho(2) and monodentate across O(5) towards Ho(1)].Isomorphous structures of polymers of PDA2- anion with other lanthanide ions La(III), Nd(III), Sm(III), and Er(III) have been reported [35, 36]. The Er-O (carboxylate) bond distances ranged from 2.239(7) to 2.677(8) Å, whereas Er-O (aqua) bond was 2.267(7) Å.In the polymeric structure of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O (1), the Ho(III) ions are interconnected through COO- groups, forming what may be viewed as an Ho-COO triple helix that extends in the crystallographic c-direction (Fig. 2). Figures 3, 4 and 5 give packing of polymer along a-, b-, and c-crystallographic directions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO-) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. One bridging COO- involves bis-monodentate syn-syn bonding (e.g., -O7-C6-O8-), whereas second and third have tridentate μ2O;κ2OO' (e.g., -O11-C21-O2- and -O13-C11-O12-) bonding modes. The regular alternating of two types of Ho(III) ions which serve as nodes for bridging dicarboxylate PDA anions generates a polymeric chain.This chain acts as SBU (secondary building block) and on further cross-linked via the -CH2C6H4CH2- spacers of the PDA anions results in 3D network of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O, which is reminiscent of the shape of a compressed honeycomb, showing 1D open channels (Fig. 5). The guest water molecules suspend in the channels and the coordinated water molecules point away from the Ho-PDA framework and into the channels. The polymer has 1D open channels when viewed along c-axis. The hydrogen atoms of guest water molecules and methylene carbon of ligand (PDA) are extensively involved in hydrogen bonding with oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups. Table 3 lists hydrogen-bond distances and angles.N2 TPD and BET surface areaThe N2 adsorption isotherm of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O (see Fig. S2, Supplementary Material) has a gradual initial uptake and shows hysteresis, which indicates presence of mesopores. The absence of a rounded knee in the isotherm indicates a weak adsorbate-adsorbent interaction. According to IUPAC classification, this coordination polymer exhibits a type IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis. The hysteresis feature of type IV isotherm is associated with capillary condensation taking place within mesopores. The hysteresis loop, which does not exhibit any limiting adsorption at high P/P0, indicates the presence of slit-shaped pores in coordination polymer network. Large gap between adsorption and desorption curves at lower P/P0 values indicates presence of ink-bottle type pores.The specific surface area determined from multipoint BET plot (see Fig. S3, Supplementary Material) is 45.37 m2/g with a slope 70.95, Y-intercept 5.80, correlation coefficient 0.998,725, and BET C constant 13.23. The value of BET C constant suggests a low heat of adsorption. The Langmuir surface area is found somewhat higher (98.62 m2/g) with a slope of 35.31, Y-intercept 8.814, correlation coefficient 0.999781, and Langmuir constant 4.0064.A t-method micropore analysis (de Boer) of polymer (see Fig. S4, Supplementary Material) gives a linear V-t-plot with Y-intercept 15.02 cm3/g and slope 1.946. The linear plot along with the non-zero intercept suggests that [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O is mesoporous. Both the micropore volume and micropore surface area are 0.023 cm3/g and 15.27 m2/g, whereas the external surface area is 30.10 m2/g with a correlation coefficient of 1.000. This is almost the same as the BET surface area. The pore size distribution pattern was obtained from desorption branch by employing the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model (see Fig. S5, Supplementary Material). The plot shows that there is a wide distribution of pores in the polymer with diameters ranging from 3 nm to more than 13 nm with an average of 5.6 nm. The total pore volume is 0.06357 cm3/g for pores smaller than 21.57 nm at P/P0 = 0.90386.Photoluminescence studiesFigure 6 shows the photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O. The excitation spectrum shows an excitation peak at about 390 nm which is assigned to 5I8 → 5G5 electronic transition in Ho3+ ion. The emission spectrum for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm shows three emission bands peaking at ~460, ~490, and ~545 nm corresponding to 5F2 → 5I8, 5F3 → 5I8, 5F4 → 5I8 transitions. Similar emission bands (not shown here) were observed with 430 nm excited wavelength. In general, purity in color of substance can be recognized by means of color coordinates. Hence, in our present work, the chromaticity coordinates of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O have been calculated from the emission spectrum using the commission international De I'Eclairage (CIE) system. The CIE chromaticity diagram for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm is shown in Fig. 7. The CIE coordinate is found to be (0.28, 0.38) which lies within the blue/hue region. Therefore, it may be concluded that the developed polymer could serve as a blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.Thermal analysisThe thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of coordination polymer [Ho2(PDA)3 H2O]n⋅2nH2O are shown in Fig. 8. The thermal decomposition was investigated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 293 to 1,273 K at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The coordination polymer network is stable up to 373 K. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve shows that decomposition of the polymer takes place in three steps. The first step starts at 373 K and ends at 463 K. The residual weight at 463 K is 88 % (calculated weight loss = 88.55 %) corresponding to loss of three water molecules and two molecules of carbon monoxide. The DTA curve has a sharp endothermic peak at 453 K, indicating the loss of three water molecules. The second step of thermal decomposition has onset at 463 K and ends at 793 K. The residual weight at 793 K is 72 % (calculated weight loss = 72.3 %) indicating the loss of four molecules of carbon monoxide and one molecule of acetaldehyde. The third step has onset from 793 K with gradual weight loss up to 1,250 K, this step involves the loss of two molecules of phenyl acetaldehyde. Sharp DTA curve at 683 K and broad DTA curve at 963 K indicate decomposition of organic ligand. The residual weight at 1,267 K is 47.5 % (calculated weight loss = 46.5 %) corresponding to formation of Ho2O3 and carbon as end product.ConclusionsThe coordination polymer diaquatris(1,4-phenylenediacetato)diholmium(III) dihydrate, [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O having three-dimensional network, has been synthesized by hydrothermal method. On the basis of physicochemical studies and single-crystal diffraction studies, we conclude that the polymer has 3D compressed honeycomb shape having 1D open channels. The polymer is porous as is evident from the BET surface area study. The photoluminescent properties indicate that polymer can serve as blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.ExperimentalAll materials used for synthesis were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on CHNS-932 Leco elemental analyzer. IR spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum RX-IFTIR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets from 400 to 4,000 cm-1. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra were measured at room temperature using Agilent Cary Eclipse Fluorescence Spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp that was used as an excitation source. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e in nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1.Diaquatris(1,4-phenylenediacetato)diholmium(III) dihydrate (1, C30H30Ho2O15)A mixture of 0.353 g Ho(NO3)3⋅5H2O (0.80 mmol) and 0.095 g 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 cm3 of deionized water and 1 cm3 of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried; Yield ~0.3 g (64 % based on H2PDA). The crystals were manually selected for structural determination and further characterization.X-ray crystallographic study: crystal structure and refinementThe structure of the compound [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. X-ray intensity data of 23,635 reflections (of which 5,379 unique) were collected on a CCD Agilent Technologies (Oxford Diffraction) SUPER NOVA diffractometer. Data were collected at 150(2) K using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The strategy for data collection was evaluated using the CrysAlisPro CCD software. The data were collected by standard ‘φ-ω' scan techniques, and were scaled and reduced using CrysAlisPro RED software. The cell dimensions were determined by least-square fit of angular settings of 23,635 reflections in the θ range 2.90°-25.00°. The intensities were measured by ω scan mode for θ range 2.90°-25.00°. Data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization factors, and absorption effects. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [37] and refined by full matrix least-squares with SHELXL-97, refining on F2 [38]. The positions of all the atoms were obtained by direct methods. All non-H-atoms were refined anisotropically. The remaining H-atoms were placed in geometrically constrained positions and refined with isotropic temperature factors, generally 1.2 Ueq of their parent atoms. Complete crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited in the CIF format with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication no. CCDC 938975. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK [fax: (44) 1223336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk].N2 TPD and BET surface areaThe specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption method using a NOVA 1200 (Quanta chrome) instrument. The bath temperature was maintained at 77 K. The sample was degassed at 423 K for 12 h before measurement. Pore size distribution and pore volume were obtained by applying the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) analysis to the adsorption branch of the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. The specific surface area of the sample was calculated using the BET method. Micropore surface area and micropore volume were determined from t-plot analysis. All the flow rates were maintained at normal temperature and pressure.AcknowledgmentsWe gratefully acknowledge financial support from DRDO, New Delhi. elements.content: Coordination polymer formulated as [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O having three-dimensional network was hydrothermally synthesized (H2PDA is 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The polymer crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 21/c, unit cell parameters: a = 21.7025(2) Ǻ, b = 10.03560(10) Ǻ, c = 14.03430(10) Ǻ, β = 91.7110(10)° (Z = 4), and exhibits a three-dimensional porous framework. The polymer contains two and four crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions and 1,4-phenylenediacetate anions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO−) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. The coordination polymer chains are reinforced by well-directed hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules. The polymer is mesoporous in nature with average pore size diameter of 5.6 nm. The polymer exhibits intense emission bands in visible region upon excitation at 390 nm. The polymer is thermally robust and undergoes thermal decomposition in well-defined steps.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Coordination polymer formulated as [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O having  three-dimensional network was hydrothermally synthesized (H2PDA is 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The polymer crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 21/c, unit cell parameters: a = 21.7025(2) Ǻ, b = 10.03560(10) Ǻ, c = 14.03430(10) Ǻ, β = 91.7110(10)° (Z = 4), and exhibits a three-dimensional porous framework. The polymer contains two and four crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions and 1,4-phenylenediacetate anions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO-) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. The coordination polymer chains are reinforced by well-directed hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules. The polymer is mesoporous in nature with average pore size diameter of 5.6 nm. The polymer exhibits intense emission bands in visible region upon excitation at 390 nm. The polymer is thermally robust and undergoes thermal decomposition in well-defined steps.

elements.content:
Introduction

Over the last two decades, developments in the field of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) achieved new height [1–4]. Coordination polymers have been synthesized rapidly because distinct voids and channels in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of current interest [5]. PCPs act as host, whereas guest molecule can be introduced reversibly without collapse of framework. Depending on flexibility of ligands which results in structural diversity, MOFs have potential applications in wide areas such as gas storage [6–8], magnetism [9], separation, optics or catalysis [10–12], luminescent materials [13–15], radiopharmaceuticals [16], optoelectronics [17, 18], and MRI contrast agents. The parameters which control desired topology and physical properties of MOFs are metal centre, coordination functional group, and as well as the geometry of the ligand molecule [19, 20]. Therefore, selection of metal centre, pillared ligand molecule, and functionality are of central importance in MOF synthesis, as these govern the self-assembly process.
elements.clean_text:
Graphical Abstract



Introduction

Over the last two decades, developments in the field of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) achieved new height [1-4]. Coordination polymers have been synthesized rapidly because distinct voids and channels in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of current interest [5]. PCPs act as host, whereas guest molecule can be introduced reversibly without collapse of framework. Depending on flexibility of ligands which results in structural diversity, MOFs have potential applications in wide areas such as gas storage [6-8], magnetism [9], separation, optics or catalysis [10-12], luminescent materials [13-15], radiopharmaceuticals [16], optoelectronics [17, 18], and MRI contrast agents. The parameters which control desired topology and physical properties of MOFs are metal centre, coordination functional group, and as well as the geometry of the ligand molecule [19, 20]. Therefore, selection of metal centre, pillared ligand molecule, and functionality are of central importance in MOF synthesis, as these govern the self-assembly process.

elements.content: The synthesis, functionality, and applications of metal-organic frameworks and self-assembled supramolecular coordination complexes have been reviewed recently [21–24]. The design and construction of lanthanide-metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) based on the judicious selection of ligands and metal ions have become a very attractive research area. The reversible incorporation of auxiliary ligand is easier in case of lanthanide–organic framework than d-block organic framework as the lanthanides have higher coordination number [25]. This high coordination number plays a crucial role in designing the different MOF architecture. It is well known that trivalent lanthanide ions are fascinating luminescence sources owing to their high color purity and relatively long lifetimes arising from electronic transitions within the partially filled 4f-shell of the ions [26, 27]. A variety of multicarboxylate triazine/imidazoline/pyridine-based MOFs containing transition and lanthanide metals have been extensively studied and found to exhibit various coordination modes accompanying diversity of structures with consequent varying adsorptions, magnetic and luminescent properties [21, 28–30]. However, among various strategies, most of the work has focused on assembly of d-block metal-organic frameworks, and analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions still remains less developed. As lanthanide ions are hard acid, they have strong attractions for the hard bases, like O− of carboxylate groups. While selecting the bridging moiety, the rigid ones get priority over flexible ones because they impart stability to lanthanides-MOF [31].

As lanthanide ions are hard acid, they have strong attractions for the hard bases, like O- of carboxylate groups. While selecting the bridging moiety, the rigid ones get priority over flexible ones because they impart stability to lanthanides-MOF [31].

elements.content: In case of porous-lanthanides organic framework, the flexibility plays a crucial role. Therefore, we have used p-phenylenediacetic acid as bridging ligand in which carboxylate groups are connected to flexible C-atom which provide open channels and voids in lanthanides-MOF. In continuation of our work on coordination polymers with multifunctional ligands [32, 33], we report here the holmium(III) coordination polymer using 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) as ligand.

elements.content: The reaction of 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) with holmium nitrate pentahydrate in the presence of ethanol and water under hydrothermal conditions resulted in formation of light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O. Polymer is stable in air and insoluble in most organic solvents. The polymer has been characterized by elemental analysis, FTIR spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, N2 TPD-BET surface area, luminescence, and TGA studies.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The reaction of 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) with holmium nitrate pentahydrate in the presence of ethanol and water under hydrothermal conditions resulted in formation of light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O. Polymer is stable in air and insoluble in most organic solvents. The polymer has been characterized by elemental analysis, FTIR spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, N2 TPD-BET surface area, luminescence, and TGA studies.

elements.content: FTIR of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O shows indicative vibrational bands of carboxylate groups and water molecules (see Fig. S1, Supplementary Material). Broad bands in the higher energy region at 3,426 and 3,029 cm−1 are attributed to υ(O–H) of coordinated and lattice water molecules. Sharp bands at 956 and 664 cm−1 are assigned to rocking ρr(H2O) and wagging ρw(H2O) modes of coordinated water molecule, respectively. Absence of bands in the region around 1,700 cm−1 indicates complete deprotonation of all the carboxylic acid groups in the polymer. The IR spectrum of polymer showed strong bands at 1,596 and 1,402 cm−1 assigned to the υas(COO) and υs(COO) modes, respectively. The in-plane δ(OCO) vibration mode appears as sharp band at 762 cm−1. Weak band at 2,924 cm−1 has been assigned to υ(C–H) of phenylene ring. The bands for δ(C–H) of phenylene ring appear at 1,325 and 868 cm−1.

FTIR spectrum of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O

FTIR of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O shows indicative vibrational bands of carboxylate groups and water molecules (see Fig. S1, Supplementary Material). Broad bands in the higher energy region at 3,426 and 3,029 cm-1 are attributed to υ(O-H) of coordinated and lattice water molecules. Sharp bands at 956 and 664 cm-1 are assigned to rocking ρr(H2O) and wagging ρw(H2O) modes of coordinated water molecule, respectively. Absence of bands in the region around 1,700 cm-1 indicates complete deprotonation of all the carboxylic acid groups in the polymer. The IR spectrum of polymer showed strong bands at 1,596 and 1,402 cm-1 assigned to the υas(COO) and υs(COO) modes, respectively. The in-plane δ(OCO) vibration mode appears as sharp band at 762 cm-1. Weak band at 2,924 cm-1 has been assigned to υ(C-H) of phenylene ring. The bands for δ(C-H) of phenylene ring appear at 1,325 and 868 cm-1.

elements.content: The crystallographic analysis of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O shows that structure of polymer consists of three-dimensional MOF with water molecules of crystallization occupying the porous voids. Relevant cell parameters and refinement results are summarized in Table 1. Two crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are present in polymer. Figure 1 shows the metal coordination environment in [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O. The coordination number around Ho(1) is nine, whereas it is eight around Ho(2). Both metal ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are coordinated to eight oxygen atoms of six carboxylate (COO−) groups of different PDA2− anions. The Ho(1) is additionally coordinated to oxygen atom of a water molecule generating a nine-coordinated tricapped trigonal prism constituted by OW(1), O(2), O(3), O(4), O(5), O(6), O(7), O(12), and O(13). The coordination geometry around eight-coordinated Ho(2) is close to dodecahedron and is constituted by O(2), O(4), O(5), O(8), O(9), O(10), O(11), and O(13).
elements.clean_text:
Description of crystal structure

The crystallographic analysis of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O shows that structure of polymer consists of three-dimensional MOF with water molecules of crystallization occupying the porous voids. Relevant cell parameters and refinement results are summarized in Table 1. Two crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are present in polymer. Figure 1 shows the metal coordination environment in [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O. The coordination number around Ho(1) is nine, whereas it is eight around Ho(2). Both metal ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] are coordinated to eight oxygen atoms of six carboxylate (COO-) groups of different PDA2- anions. The Ho(1) is additionally coordinated to oxygen atom of a water molecule generating a nine-coordinated tricapped trigonal prism constituted by OW(1), O(2), O(3), O(4), O(5), O(6), O(7), O(12), and O(13). The coordination geometry around eight-coordinated Ho(2) is close to dodecahedron and is constituted by O(2), O(4), O(5), O(8), O(9), O(10), O(11), and O(13).

elements.content: The Ho–O (carboxylate) bond distances range from 2.255(2) to 2.703(3) Å and bond length of Ho–O (aqua) bond is 2.370(3) Å. All the bond lengths are within the range of those observed for other eight- or nine-coordinate Ho(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands [34]. Selected bond distances and angles are presented in Table 2. There are four crystallographically independent dicarboxylate PDA2− ligands in polymer [PDA(1), PDA(2), PDA(3), and PDA(4)] corresponding to O(11)O(2)C(21), O(7)O(8)C(6), O(6)O(9)C(26)C(1)O(3)O(4), and O(12)O(13)C(11)C(15)O(5)O(10) sets of atoms, respectively. Different modes of bonding adopted by PDA2− ligand are presented in Scheme 1. All four PDAs [PDA(1), PDA(2), PDA(3), and PDA(4)] use two carboxylate groups to coordinate the holmium atoms but through different coordination modes. PDA(1) adopts the μ2O;κ2OO′ coordination mode [bidentate through O(2) and O(11) toward Ho(2) and monodentate across O(2) towards Ho(1), and the atoms symmetry-related], whereas PDA(2) acts as a tetrakis-monodentate ligand [from O(7) and O(8) toward Ho(1) and Ho(2), respectively, and the atoms related by the inversion center]. PDA(3) acts as a bridge through its two carboxylate groups, one of them [O(6)-C(26)-O(9)] adopting the syn–syn coordination mode [coordination of O(6) and O(9) to Ho(1) and Ho(2), respectively] and the other [O(3)-C(1)-O(4)] exhibiting μ2O;κ2OO′ coordination mode [bidentate through O(3) and O(4) toward Ho(1) and monodentate across O(4) towards Ho(2)]. PDA(4) also adopts the μ2O;κ2OO′ coordination mode through its both carboxylate groups [bidentate through O(12) and O(13) toward Ho(1) and monodentate across O(13) towards Ho(2); bidentate through O(5) and O(10) toward Ho(2) and monodentate across O(5) towards Ho(1)].

elements.content: In the polymeric structure of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O (1), the Ho(III) ions are interconnected through COO− groups, forming what may be viewed as an Ho-COO triple helix that extends in the crystallographic c-direction (Fig. 2). Figures 3, 4 and 5 give packing of polymer along a-, b-, and c-crystallographic directions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions [Ho(1) and Ho(2)] adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO−) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. One bridging COO− involves bis-monodentate syn–syn bonding (e.g., –O7–C6–O8–), whereas second and third have tridentate μ2O;κ2OO′ (e.g., –O11–C21–O2– and –O13–C11–O12–) bonding modes. The regular alternating of two types of Ho(III) ions which serve as nodes for bridging dicarboxylate PDA anions generates a polymeric chain.

elements.content: This chain acts as SBU (secondary building block) and on further cross-linked via the –CH2C6H4CH2– spacers of the PDA anions results in 3D network of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O, which is reminiscent of the shape of a compressed honeycomb, showing 1D open channels (Fig. 5). The guest water molecules suspend in the channels and the coordinated water molecules point away from the Ho-PDA framework and into the channels. The polymer has 1D open channels when viewed along c-axis. The hydrogen atoms of guest water molecules and methylene carbon of ligand (PDA) are extensively involved in hydrogen bonding with oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups. Table 3 lists hydrogen-bond distances and angles.

The guest water molecules suspend in the channels and the coordinated water molecules point away from the Ho-PDA framework and into the channels. The polymer has 1D open channels when viewed along c-axis. The hydrogen atoms of guest water molecules and methylene carbon of ligand (PDA) are extensively involved in hydrogen bonding with oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups. Table 3 lists hydrogen-bond distances and angles.

The N2 adsorption isotherm of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O (see Fig. S2, Supplementary Material) has a gradual initial uptake and shows hysteresis, which indicates presence of mesopores. The absence of a rounded knee in the isotherm indicates a weak adsorbate–adsorbent interaction. According to IUPAC classification, this coordination polymer exhibits a type IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis. The hysteresis feature of type IV isotherm is associated with capillary condensation taking place within mesopores. The hysteresis loop, which does not exhibit any limiting adsorption at high P/P0, indicates the presence of slit-shaped pores in coordination polymer network. Large gap between adsorption and desorption curves at lower P/P0 values indicates presence of ink-bottle type pores.

elements.content: A t-method micropore analysis (de Boer) of polymer (see Fig. S4, Supplementary Material) gives a linear V–t–plot with Y-intercept 15.02 cm3/g and slope 1.946. The linear plot along with the non-zero intercept suggests that [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O is mesoporous. Both the micropore volume and micropore surface area are 0.023 cm3/g and 15.27 m2/g, whereas the external surface area is 30.10 m2/g with a correlation coefficient of 1.000. This is almost the same as the BET surface area. The pore size distribution pattern was obtained from desorption branch by employing the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model (see Fig. S5, Supplementary Material). The plot shows that there is a wide distribution of pores in the polymer with diameters ranging from 3 nm to more than 13 nm with an average of 5.6 nm. The total pore volume is 0.06357 cm3/g for pores smaller than 21.57 nm at P/P0 = 0.90386.

elements.content: Figure 6 shows the photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O. The excitation spectrum shows an excitation peak at about 390 nm which is assigned to 5I8 → 5G5 electronic transition in Ho3+ ion. The emission spectrum for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm shows three emission bands peaking at ~460, ~490, and ~545 nm corresponding to 5F2 → 5I8, 5F3 → 5I8, 5F4 → 5I8 transitions. Similar emission bands (not shown here) were observed with 430 nm excited wavelength. In general, purity in color of substance can be recognized by means of color coordinates. Hence, in our present work, the chromaticity coordinates of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O have been calculated from the emission spectrum using the commission international De I’Eclairage (CIE) system. The CIE chromaticity diagram for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm is shown in Fig. 7. The CIE coordinate is found to be (0.28, 0.38) which lies within the blue/hue region. Therefore, it may be concluded that the developed polymer could serve as a blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of coordination polymer [Ho2(PDA)3 H2O]n·2nH2O are shown in Fig. 8. The thermal decomposition was investigated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 293 to 1,273 K at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The coordination polymer network is stable up to 373 K. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve shows that decomposition of the polymer takes place in three steps. The first step starts at 373 K and ends at 463 K. The residual weight at 463 K is 88 % (calculated weight loss = 88.55 %) corresponding to loss of three water molecules and two molecules of carbon monoxide. The DTA curve has a sharp endothermic peak at 453 K, indicating the loss of three water molecules. The second step of thermal decomposition has onset at 463 K and ends at 793 K. The residual weight at 793 K is 72 % (calculated weight loss = 72.3 %) indicating the loss of four molecules of carbon monoxide and one molecule of acetaldehyde. The third step has onset from 793 K with gradual weight loss up to 1,250 K, this step involves the loss of two molecules of phenyl acetaldehyde. Sharp DTA curve at 683 K and broad DTA curve at 963 K indicate decomposition of organic ligand. The residual weight at 1,267 K is 47.5 % (calculated weight loss = 46.5 %) corresponding to formation of Ho2O3 and carbon as end product.

elements.content: The coordination polymer diaquatris(1,4-phenylenediacetato)diholmium(III) dihydrate, [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O having three-dimensional network, has been synthesized by hydrothermal method. On the basis of physicochemical studies and single-crystal diffraction studies, we conclude that the polymer has 3D compressed honeycomb shape having 1D open channels. The polymer is porous as is evident from the BET surface area study. The photoluminescent properties indicate that polymer can serve as blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The coordination polymer diaquatris(1,4-phenylenediacetato)diholmium(III) dihydrate, [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O having three-dimensional network, has been synthesized by hydrothermal method. On the basis of physicochemical studies and single-crystal diffraction studies, we conclude that the polymer has 3D compressed honeycomb shape having 1D open channels. The polymer is porous as is evident from the BET surface area study. The photoluminescent properties indicate that polymer can serve as blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.

elements.content: All materials used for synthesis were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on CHNS-932 Leco elemental analyzer. IR spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum RX-IFTIR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets from 400 to 4,000 cm−1. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra were measured at room temperature using Agilent Cary Eclipse Fluorescence Spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp that was used as an excitation source. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e in nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

Experimental

All materials used for synthesis were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on CHNS-932 Leco elemental analyzer. IR spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum RX-IFTIR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets from 400 to 4,000 cm-1. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra were measured at room temperature using Agilent Cary Eclipse Fluorescence Spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp that was used as an excitation source. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e in nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1.

elements.content: A mixture of 0.353 g Ho(NO3)3·5H2O (0.80 mmol) and 0.095 g 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 cm3 of deionized water and 1 cm3 of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried; Yield ~0.3 g (64 % based on H2PDA). The crystals were manually selected for structural determination and further characterization.

Diaquatris(1,4-phenylenediacetato)diholmium(III) dihydrate (1, C30H30Ho2O15)

A mixture of 0.353 g Ho(NO3)3⋅5H2O (0.80 mmol) and 0.095 g 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (0.49 mmol) was placed in a Teflon-lined Parr bomb containing 10 cm3 of deionized water and 1 cm3 of ethanol. The bomb was sealed, heated at 170 °C for 3 days, and allowed to cool to room temperature. Light brown crystals of [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O were isolated by decanting the supernatant, washed thoroughly with deionized water, ethanol, and acetone, and air-dried; Yield ~0.3 g (64 % based on H2PDA). The crystals were manually selected for structural determination and further characterization.

elements.content: The structure of the compound [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. X-ray intensity data of 23,635 reflections (of which 5,379 unique) were collected on a CCD Agilent Technologies (Oxford Diffraction) SUPER NOVA diffractometer. Data were collected at 150(2) K using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The strategy for data collection was evaluated using the CrysAlisPro CCD software. The data were collected by standard ‘φ–ω’ scan techniques, and were scaled and reduced using CrysAlisPro RED software. The cell dimensions were determined by least-square fit of angular settings of 23,635 reflections in the θ range 2.90°–25.00°. The intensities were measured by ω scan mode for θ range 2.90°–25.00°. Data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization factors, and absorption effects. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [37] and refined by full matrix least-squares with SHELXL-97, refining on F2 [38]. The positions of all the atoms were obtained by direct methods. All non-H-atoms were refined anisotropically. The remaining H-atoms were placed in geometrically constrained positions and refined with isotropic temperature factors, generally 1.2 Ueq of their parent atoms. Complete crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited in the CIF format with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication no. CCDC 938975. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK [fax: (44) 1223336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk].

X-ray crystallographic study: crystal structure and refinement

The structure of the compound [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. X-ray intensity data of 23,635 reflections (of which 5,379 unique) were collected on a CCD Agilent Technologies (Oxford Diffraction) SUPER NOVA diffractometer. Data were collected at 150(2) K using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The strategy for data collection was evaluated using the CrysAlisPro CCD software. The data were collected by standard ‘φ-ω' scan techniques, and were scaled and reduced using CrysAlisPro RED software. The cell dimensions were determined by least-square fit of angular settings of 23,635 reflections in the θ range 2.90°-25.00°. The intensities were measured by ω scan mode for θ range 2.90°-25.00°. Data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization factors, and absorption effects. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [37] and refined by full matrix least-squares with SHELXL-97, refining on F2 [38]. The positions of all the atoms were obtained by direct methods. All non-H-atoms were refined anisotropically. The remaining H-atoms were placed in geometrically constrained positions and refined with isotropic temperature factors, generally 1.2 Ueq of their parent atoms. Complete crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited in the CIF format with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication no. CCDC 938975. Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK [fax: (44) 1223336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk].

elements.content: The specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter were measured by N2 adsorption–desorption method using a NOVA 1200 (Quanta chrome) instrument. The bath temperature was maintained at 77 K. The sample was degassed at 423 K for 12 h before measurement. Pore size distribution and pore volume were obtained by applying the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) analysis to the adsorption branch of the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms. The specific surface area of the sample was calculated using the BET method. Micropore surface area and micropore volume were determined from t-plot analysis. All the flow rates were maintained at normal temperature and pressure.

The specific surface area of the sample was calculated using the BET method. Micropore surface area and micropore volume were determined from t-plot analysis. cln_elements.content:
Coordination polymer formulated as [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n·2nH2O having three-dimensional network was hydrothermally synthesized (H2PDA is 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The polymer crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 21/c, unit cell parameters: a = 21.7025(2) Ǻ, b = 10.03560(10) Ǻ, c = 14.03430(10) Ǻ, β = 91.7110(10)° (Z = 4), and exhibits a three-dimensional porous framework. The polymer contains two and four crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions and 1,4-phenylenediacetate anions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO−) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. The coordination polymer chains are reinforced by well-directed hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules. The polymer is mesoporous in nature with average pore size diameter of 5.6 nm. The polymer exhibits intense emission bands in visible region upon excitation at 390 nm. The polymer is thermally robust and undergoes thermal decomposition in well-defined steps.

The specific surface area determined from multipoint BET plot (see Fig. S3, Supplementary Material) is 45.37 m2/g with a slope 70.95, Y-intercept 5.80, correlation coefficient 0.998,725, and BET C constant 13.23. The value of BET C constant suggests a low heat of adsorption. The Langmuir surface area is found somewhat higher (98.62 m2/g) with a slope of 35.31, Y-intercept 8.814, correlation coefficient 0.999781, and Langmuir constant 4.0064.

A t-method micropore analysis (de Boer) of polymer (see Fig. S4, Supplementary Material) gives a linear V–t–plot with Y-intercept 15.02 cm3/g and slope 1.946. The linear plot along with the non-zero intercept suggests that [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O is mesoporous. Both the micropore volume and micropore surface area are 0.023 cm3/g and 15.27 m2/g, whereas the external surface area is 30.10 m2/g with a correlation coefficient of 1.000. This is almost the same as the BET surface area. The pore size distribution pattern was obtained from desorption branch by employing the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model (see Fig. S5, Supplementary Material). The plot shows that there is a wide distribution of pores in the polymer with diameters ranging from 3 nm to more than 13 nm with an average of 5.6 nm. The total pore volume is 0.06357 cm3/g for pores smaller than 21.57 nm at P/P0 = 0.90386.

Photoluminescence studies

Figure 6 shows the photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O. The excitation spectrum shows an excitation peak at about 390 nm which is assigned to 5I8 → 5G5 electronic transition in Ho3+ ion. The emission spectrum for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm shows three emission bands peaking at ~460, ~490, and ~545 nm corresponding to 5F2 → 5I8, 5F3 → 5I8, 5F4 → 5I8 transitions. Similar emission bands (not shown here) were observed with 430 nm excited wavelength. In general, purity in color of substance can be recognized by means of color coordinates. Hence, in our present work, the chromaticity coordinates of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O have been calculated from the emission spectrum using the commission international De I’Eclairage (CIE) system. The CIE chromaticity diagram for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n·2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm is shown in Fig. 7. The CIE coordinate is found to be (0.28, 0.38) which lies within the blue/hue region. Therefore, it may be concluded that the developed polymer could serve as a blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.

Thermal analysis

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of coordination polymer [Ho2(PDA)3 H2O]n·2nH2O are shown in Fig. 8. The thermal decomposition was investigated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 293 to 1,273 K at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The coordination polymer network is stable up to 373 K. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve shows that decomposition of the polymer takes place in three steps. The first step starts at 373 K and ends at 463 K. The residual weight at 463 K is 88 % (calculated weight loss = 88.55 %) corresponding to loss of three water molecules and two molecules of carbon monoxide. The DTA curve has a sharp endothermic peak at 453 K, indicating the loss of three water molecules. The second step of thermal decomposition has onset at 463 K and ends at 793 K. The residual weight at 793 K is 72 % (calculated weight loss = 72.3 %) indicating the loss of four molecules of carbon monoxide and one molecule of acetaldehyde. The third step has onset from 793 K with gradual weight loss up to 1,250 K, this step involves the loss of two molecules of phenyl acetaldehyde. Sharp DTA curve at 683 K and broad DTA curve at 963 K indicate decomposition of organic ligand. The residual weight at 1,267 K is 47.5 % (calculated weight loss = 46.5 %) corresponding to formation of Ho2O3 and carbon as end product.

Abstract

Coordination polymer formulated as [Ho2(PDA)3(H2O)]n⋅2nH2O having  three-dimensional network was hydrothermally synthesized (H2PDA is 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid). The polymer crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P 21/c, unit cell parameters: a = 21.7025(2) Ǻ, b = 10.03560(10) Ǻ, c = 14.03430(10) Ǻ, β = 91.7110(10)° (Z = 4), and exhibits a three-dimensional porous framework. The polymer contains two and four crystallographically independent holmium(III) ions and 1,4-phenylenediacetate anions, respectively. The two types of Ho(III) ions adopt an extended zigzag orientation and act as nodes alternately, while three different carboxylate (COO-) groups bridge two adjacent Ho(III) ions. The coordination polymer chains are reinforced by well-directed hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules. The polymer is mesoporous in nature with average pore size diameter of 5.6 nm. The polymer exhibits intense emission bands in visible region upon excitation at 390 nm. The polymer is thermally robust and undergoes thermal decomposition in well-defined steps.

The specific surface area determined from multipoint BET plot (see Fig. S3, Supplementary Material) is 45.37 m2/g with a slope 70.95, Y-intercept 5.80, correlation coefficient 0.998,725, and BET C constant 13.23. The value of BET C constant suggests a low heat of adsorption. The Langmuir surface area is found somewhat higher (98.62 m2/g) with a slope of 35.31, Y-intercept 8.814, correlation coefficient 0.999781, and Langmuir constant 4.0064.

A t-method micropore analysis (de Boer) of polymer (see Fig. S4, Supplementary Material) gives a linear V-t-plot with Y-intercept 15.02 cm3/g and slope 1.946. The linear plot along with the non-zero intercept suggests that [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O is mesoporous. Both the micropore volume and micropore surface area are 0.023 cm3/g and 15.27 m2/g, whereas the external surface area is 30.10 m2/g with a correlation coefficient of 1.000. This is almost the same as the BET surface area. The pore size distribution pattern was obtained from desorption branch by employing the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model (see Fig. S5, Supplementary Material). The plot shows that there is a wide distribution of pores in the polymer with diameters ranging from 3 nm to more than 13 nm with an average of 5.6 nm. The total pore volume is 0.06357 cm3/g for pores smaller than 21.57 nm at P/P0 = 0.90386.

Photoluminescence studies

Figure 6 shows the photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O. The excitation spectrum shows an excitation peak at about 390 nm which is assigned to 5I8 → 5G5 electronic transition in Ho3+ ion. The emission spectrum for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm shows three emission bands peaking at ~460, ~490, and ~545 nm corresponding to 5F2 → 5I8, 5F3 → 5I8, 5F4 → 5I8 transitions. Similar emission bands (not shown here) were observed with 430 nm excited wavelength. In general, purity in color of substance can be recognized by means of color coordinates. Hence, in our present work, the chromaticity coordinates of [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O have been calculated from the emission spectrum using the commission international De I'Eclairage (CIE) system. The CIE chromaticity diagram for [Ho2(PDA)3H2O]n⋅2nH2O upon excitation at 390 nm is shown in Fig. 7. The CIE coordinate is found to be (0.28, 0.38) which lies within the blue/hue region. Therefore, it may be concluded that the developed polymer could serve as a blue/hue producing material for display applications and light emitting diodes.

Thermal analysis

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of coordination polymer [Ho2(PDA)3 H2O]n⋅2nH2O are shown in Fig. 8. The thermal decomposition was investigated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 293 to 1,273 K at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The coordination polymer network is stable up to 373 K. The thermogravimetry (TG) curve shows that decomposition of the polymer takes place in three steps. The first step starts at 373 K and ends at 463 K. The residual weight at 463 K is 88 % (calculated weight loss = 88.55 %) corresponding to loss of three water molecules and two molecules of carbon monoxide. The DTA curve has a sharp endothermic peak at 453 K, indicating the loss of three water molecules. The second step of thermal decomposition has onset at 463 K and ends at 793 K. The residual weight at 793 K is 72 % (calculated weight loss = 72.3 %) indicating the loss of four molecules of carbon monoxide and one molecule of acetaldehyde. The third step has onset from 793 K with gradual weight loss up to 1,250 K, this step involves the loss of two molecules of phenyl acetaldehyde. Sharp DTA curve at 683 K and broad DTA curve at 963 K indicate decomposition of organic ligand. The residual weight at 1,267 K is 47.5 % (calculated weight loss = 46.5 %) corresponding to formation of Ho2O3 and carbon as end product.
